speaker: Speaker 0
text: Welcome to Collins French with Paul Noble. Content copyright Paul Noble, 2010.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: I'm Paul Noble.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Over the years, I've taught many, many people.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Curiously, they have each had much the same story to tell regarding their previous experiences of language learning.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: As a result, these days, when I first start a teaching session, I ask my students to raise their hands if they have had any of the following experiences. "Raise your hand," I say, "if you studied a language for several years at school, but came out unable to really say anything.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Or if you have ever bought a language course and given up around page 30, somewhere around Chapter 2. Or if you have ever felt more confused by a teacher's explanation of the language than by the language itself.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Perhaps you've been amazed by just how closely grammar books resemble furniture assembly instructions.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Or you may have felt that you are in fact more or less incapable of learning a foreign language."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Invariably, when I ask these questions, all the students soon have at least one hand in the air, and they laugh.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: They laugh because for some reason, our language learning experiences tend to be very similar. And sadly, these similar experiences tend not to be very good ones.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: My own initial experience with language learning were also uncannily similar to those I've just described.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: In fact, when I ask my students these questions, my own hand is the first to go up, and it stays up until we have gone through them all.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: However, these less than positive experiences have had an upside both for myself and for those individuals I have taught,

speaker: Paul Noble
text: because these experiences, along with a number of other factors, have helped inform and shape the method that will be used during this course.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Using this method, you will learn how to communicate in French and how to formulate your own ideas and thoughts using French.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: As you learn with it, you will quickly discover that I do not use complicated grammatical explanations at all, and I will not ask you to memorize long lists of vocabulary.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: The way the course is structured will by itself ensure that you remember what you are taught.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Instead, through your interaction with the CDs, I will lead you through the French language, enabling you to build up complex sentences by yourself, step by step, so that you are actually speaking independently in French by the end of the course.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And this is regardless of how little or how much you know when you begin.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: You will also discover that the language I teach is designed to be adaptable,

speaker: Paul Noble
text: so you'll be able to use it just as easily for holidaying in a French-speaking country as for living or working in one.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: It'll be just as easy to use it to order a coffee as to hold a conversation with the waiter who brings it to you.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And again, all of this regardless of how little or how much you know when you begin.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: This method has already proved extremely successful with a very great many students, including hundreds of so-called "no-hopers".

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Interestingly, not one of these students failed to learn using this method.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: It is these many success cases, letters of thank you, and even the occasional hug, that have made teaching languages so very worthwhile for me, and it is this that has persuaded me to publish my courses here for the first time.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: I anticipate and hope that they will be as effective for you as they have been for so many of my other students. Au revoir, and good luck.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Before we begin, I do need to establish three parameters, or three main ground rules for you to follow when you use the course.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: The first is that I want you to take time to think out your answers when you're doing the course.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Natural-length pauses have been included in the course anyway, but if you feel you need longer to think out or work out your answer, simply pause the course and think about it for a moment.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: The second ground rule, and perhaps the most important,

speaker: Paul Noble
text: is that I don't want you to make an effort to remember the things I'm teaching you.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: In fact, strange as it might sound, it doesn't particularly bother me if you forget something when I first introduce it. The reason for this is that when people try to memorize things, perhaps lists of vocabularies or grammar rules or something like that,

speaker: Paul Noble
text: they tend not to be able to actually use them when they're speaking the language. They cram them into their heads, but they're not necessarily able to use them very easily. And actually, they still tend to forget them at the crucial moment.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: The way that we remember things so that we actually retain them and can use them is through usage and through being introduced to something again and again. For instance, if you follow a sport or a program on the television, you'll find you know all about the people who are participate in that, whether it's people who play sports or whether it's actors in a drama. You'll know all about them, but you will never have made a conscious effort to actually memorize their names or what it is they do on the program.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Instead, by seeing the same program again and again, slowly over time, you'll simply remember it. And that's what will happen in this course.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: I'll introduce certain concepts, certain words, and you'll hear them and you'll use them, and then

speaker: Paul Noble
text: we'll forget about them for a moment, and I'll let you forget about them.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Later on in the course, I'll bring them up a second time, by which point, you might well not remember them. But it's this exact action of you being reminded of something and then allowed to forget it, and then reminded again, and then allowed to forget it, and then reminded again, that will eventually allow you to remember what I've taught you by itself. You won't need to try to remember any of it. You won't need to try to memorize any of it. All you need to do is take part in the course and trust that I will bring it up again later and will remind you so that by the end of the course, you'll remember it automatically without ever actually having tried to remember anything. This is what I do with my students, and this is what I'll do with you here.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: The final ground rule is that I don't want you to worry about making mistakes.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: When you learn a new language, you will inevitably make mistakes.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And I think that because we get so used to speaking our own languages perfectly, we find it very hard, particularly as adults, to make mistakes when we're speaking out loud.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: You'll find, however, that the beauty of using this method is that you will instantly know when you've made a mistake, and you'll also find out why.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: This will allow you to change what you're doing and to make rapid progress in the language.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And so by making these mistakes and knowing how to correct them yourself, you'll find that you very quickly go from a non-speaker of the language to being someone who can communicate in it with a surprising degree of confidence, even after just a few hours of studying it.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So again, to sum up these three ground rules. Firstly, take your time to work out your answer and to think about it. If you need to pause the course, you can do that. It's fine. Go at your own pace.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Second ground rule is don't sit there trying to remember what it is I'm teaching on the course. Just go with the flow of the course. Take your time to do it, but don't sit there worrying you've forgotten a word. I'll actually be expecting you to forget some of the things as I teach you so that I get a chance to remind you of them later, and they will come up again, and you will be reminded of them until you remember them. Without making any effort on your part to do so, you will simply know those words and those rules by the end of the course.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And the final rule, don't worry about making a mistake. We learn from mistakes and we benefit from them, particularly when we're learning to speak a second language.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So,

speaker: Paul Noble
text: don't worry about any of these things. Leave your learning of the language to me.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Although you may be only vaguely aware of it, English and French are in fact very closely related languages. I think we're all aware of what happened in 1066, or at least most of us are.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: There was an invasion in Britain into England by the, the Normans.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And the Normans spoke French, and they brought French to the British Isles.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: As a result of that, it has left a, a linguistic legacy in English, which is that five or six out of every 10 words in English have come into English through French.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: This gives us a big, big advantage when learning French, if, if we utilize these words, that is. I mean, uh, frequently that's not the case, but we will be using them here, because they are one of the biggest advantages we have. As speakers of English, you'll find that these words tend to be the longer ones in English. Uh, the shorter words tend to be of Germanic Anglo-Saxon origin. So, we have, we have this division in English. Normally, I would say typically, um, words seven or eight letters in length or longer tend to be of French/Latin origin, and shorter than that tend typically to be of Germanic/Anglo-Saxon origin. What it means is it's very easy to use these longer words for when English speakers are speaking French. Not only this, um, but there are also more recent French additions to the English language which still feel French.
